stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the initial concept and 3D modeling for a new level, Course 11. He pivoted the theme from a volcano to a Bowser-themed oil rig/airship factory and spent the stream experimenting with layouts, platform ideas, and finding a suitable visual style for the level's large rock spires. He also had a spontaneous idea to redesign parts of Course 1.

development_findings.summary: Course 11's theme has been changed from a volcano to a Bowser-themed oil rig and airship factory.
development_findings.quote: the whole volcano theme is gone now we want it to be something like this

development_findings.summary: For the complex oil rig level, Kaze is adopting an unusual, bottom-up design process: creating various assets first and then arranging them, rather than planning the full layout from the start.
development_findings.quote: it's probably best we just make a few random assets for now, and then just see how we can combine them to look good. This is usually not how we make levels, but for this level, it might be the best.

development_findings.summary: Kaze had a spontaneous idea to redesign the first star of Course 1 to add more verticality and length, involving climbing a tree and using a windmill.
development_findings.quote: you just spin on top of the windmill and the star kind of just takes you around the whole level like that, with a lot of vertical platforming.

development_findings.summary: The working title for Course 11 is 'Frantic Fleet Factory', which follows the game's naming convention of alliterations or rhymes.
development_findings.quote: Frantic Fleet Factory is the current name I'm thinking of.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explained his design principle that creativity must be purposeful and focused on solving specific design problems, rather than just incorporating random ideas.
development_findings.quote: designing something is not just about coming up with ideas it's about solving whatever problem you have in design

development_findings.summary: Kaze outlined a detailed mission structure for Course 11, involving a worker strike, operating a crane to destroy a Bowser statue, exploring a power generator, and a final boss area on a blimp landing pad.
He adjusted the game's watercolor to have a bluer, less black tone to better represent oily water instead of lava.
Kaze mentioned the next planned course after the oil rig is a Wild West-themed level focused on 'catching bad guys'.
Multi-language support is a possibility for the game, as a community member named Rionu has persistently offered to handle translations.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a design philosophy that modern games often lack true freedom, feeling more like following instructions than playing. He aims to avoid this in his own designs.
context_findings.quote: I feel like there are so many video games where there is no solution right off the bat And I know that I just have to follow these instructions that I have already predefined like months ago to solve the game And it's like I'm not even playing, I'm actually just following instructions I've laid out myself.

context_findings.summary: Kaze commented on the risk of releasing a ROM hack close to a major Nintendo game release, citing Nintendo's history of taking legal action against fan projects during those times.
context_findings.quote: nintendo also has a habit of going after ROM hack right after they release their own games so that is a pretty ballsy move to do

context_findings.summary: The project's working title is "Return to Yoshi's Island 64", but Kaze is concerned that it might not be optimal for searchability.
context_findings.quote: the name is weird i'm planning to call it return to yoshi's island 64 that's the current name but like it might not be the most searchable name

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about a non-work activity he did with his spouse, Zeina, indicating a work-life balance and a close personal relationship.
context_findings.quote: Me and Zeina, we went out and we made a cool... We made a terrarium in a closed jar.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for animations needed for an end cutscene, and Kaze's progress on that specific task is dependent on her work.
zeina.quote: I still also need to do the end cutscene, but I was waiting for the animations for Zeina first. They took a while.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned going out with Zeina to make a terrarium, showing their personal relationship outside of the project.

key_stories.title: The Spire Conundrum
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to design the main terrain for the new oil rig level, cycling through multiple unsatisfying ideas for mountains and spires. He eventually found inspiration in a fantasy art piece, leading him to create a modular, 'Mario-esque' rock formation that solved key visual and gameplay challenges, providing a foundation for the level's layout.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to design the core landmass for the new oil rig level (Course 11), struggling to find a concept that was visually interesting, thematically appropriate, and functionally clear for platforming.
key_stories.process: Kaze switched the level theme from volcano to oil rig. He sought inspiration from Rico Harbor and real oil rigs, but struggled with creating large platforms. He then explored chat's suggestion of 'ocean spires,' iterating through several designs (including ones inspired by New Super Mario Bros.) that he ultimately rejected for being visually confusing or technically problematic. Finally, a new reference image led to a breakthrough design that he was satisfied with.
key_stories.outcome: After multiple failed experiments with different mountain styles, Kaze discovered a reference for a fantasy-style, blocky rock spire. He successfully modeled a modular, low-polygon version that clearly defines walkable paths, solving both the aesthetic and gameplay problem.
key_stories.key_quote: I finally have the thing that I want... this is gonna look very Mario esque as well which is why I like this idea so much and there will be no confusion about where you can and can't stand.

key_stories.title: Spontaneous Course 1 Redesign
key_stories.summary: In a moment of sudden inspiration while working on a different level, Kaze decided to completely redesign the first star of Course 1. He devised a new, more vertical path to make the game's opening moments more engaging, showcasing his iterative and non-linear creative process.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt that the path for the first star in the game's opening level (Course 1) was too short and lacked engaging vertical platforming.
key_stories.process: While working on the much later Course 11, Kaze was spontaneously reminded of his dissatisfaction with Course 1. He immediately paused his current work to verbally sketch out a completely new path, proposing to add a tree and move a windmill to create a fun, vertical route around the level.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now has a concrete plan to significantly revise Course 1, Star 1, to create a more dynamic and lengthy introduction to the game's platforming.
key_stories.key_quote: Here we go again. I know, I know, here we go again, but look, my idea for Course 1.
